body.p:
Bowling Green Ky Feb. 6th 1864
To His Excellency Thomas E. Bramlette
Gov. State of Kentucky

Your petitioner Mary W. Smith, would respectfully represent, that she confessed a judgment for Sixty Dollars, upon an Indictment for keeping a tippling House, at the present term of the Warren Equity & Criminal Court. The facts of the case are these. She proposed to open a Hotel in the town of Bowling Green and being a widow woman employed a young man by name of J. R. Newton to attend to Her the business of said House and as such to procure the necessary License for same. He obtained the municipal License for $150.00 and the United States License for $45.00 and thinking the License for keeping Said House complete, he failed to obtain the State License from the county Court ^$10^ and never knew but what her License was complete, until She was indicted. She says She never intentionally violated the law and requests a remission of said fine at your hands --

M W Smith
J. R. Newton
Sworn to before me by Mary W. Smith and J. R. Newton this Feb. 6th 1864
We the undersigned cheerfully unite with the petitioner in her prayer for the remission of the fine mentioned in the within

W. D. Helm
D. W. Wright
H H Skiles
J C Walker
J. E. Halsell

Warren Co.
Relief Refused
Tho. E. Bramlette
64
